title: ICASSP_2016_11_abs

sentences.text: The problem of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals is addressed through a method relying on nonstationarity of the original signals .
The signals are assumed to be piecewise stationary with varying variances in different epochs .
In comparison with previous works , in this paper it is assumed that the signals are not i.i.d. in each epoch , but obey a first-order autoregressive model .
This model was shown to be more appropriate for blind separation of natural speech signals .
A separation method is proposed that is nearly statistically efficient -LRB- approaching the corresponding Cramér-Rao lower bound -RRB- , if the separated signals obey the assumed model .
In the case of natural speech signals , the method is shown to have separation accuracy better than the state-of-the-art methods .

Entity-this_paper.label: this paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents a method for blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals, assuming that the signals follow a first-order autoregressive model rather than being independent and identically distributed, which is shown to be more effective for separating natural speech signals.

Entity-separation_method.label: separation method
Entity-separation_method.description: The separation method refers to a proposed algorithm for blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals, which utilizes a first-order autoregressive model to achieve nearly statistically efficient separation accuracy, particularly for natural speech signals.

Entity-blind_separation_of_underdetermin.label: blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals
aliases: blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals
Entity-blind_separation_of_underdetermin.description: The blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals refers to a signal processing problem where the goal is to recover individual source signals from a mixture that contains fewer observed signals than sources, utilizing methods that exploit the nonstationary characteristics of the signals.

mentions.local_name: blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals

Entity-blind_separation_of_natural_speec.label: blind separation of natural speech signals
aliases: blind separation of natural speech signals
Entity-blind_separation_of_natural_speec.description: Blind separation of natural speech signals refers to a method for isolating individual speech signals from a mixture of overlapping audio sources without prior knowledge of the signals, utilizing statistical models that account for the nonstationarity and autoregressive properties of the speech signals.

mentions.local_name: blind separation of natural speech signals

Entity-a_method_relying_on_nonstationari.label: a method relying on nonstationarity of the original signals
aliases: a method relying on nonstationarity of the original signals
Entity-a_method_relying_on_nonstationari.description: A method for blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals that utilizes the nonstationarity of the original signals, assuming they are piecewise stationary with varying variances and following a first-order autoregressive model.

mentions.local_name: a method relying on nonstationarity of the original signals

Entity-blind_separation.label: blind separation
Entity-blind_separation.description: Blind separation is a signal processing technique used to separate mixed signals into their original independent components without prior knowledge of the mixing process.

Entity-original_signal.label: original signals
Entity-original_signal.description: The term 'original signals' refers to the independent signals that are being analyzed for blind separation in the context of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures, characterized by their nonstationarity and piecewise stationary properties.

Entity-separated_signal.label: separated signals
Entity-separated_signal.description: Separated signals refer to the independent signals that have been extracted from a mixture using a proposed separation method that assumes a first-order autoregressive model for improved accuracy in the context of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures.

Entity-independent_signal.label: independent signals
Entity-independent_signal.description: Independent signals refer to the original source signals that are mixed together in an underdetermined instantaneous mixture, which are assumed to be nonstationary and piecewise stationary with varying variances, and are the focus of a method for blind separation in the context of signal processing.

Entity-underdetermined_instantaneous_mix.label: underdetermined instantaneous mixtures
Entity-underdetermined_instantaneous_mix.description: Underdetermined instantaneous mixtures refer to a type of signal mixture problem where the number of observed signals is less than the number of independent source signals, complicating the task of blind separation due to the nonstationary nature of the signals involved.

Entity-model.label: model
Entity-model.description: The 'model' refers to a first-order autoregressive model that is assumed to describe the behavior of piecewise stationary signals for the purpose of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals, particularly in the context of natural speech signals.

Entity-signal.label: signals
Entity-signal.description: The term 'signals' refers to the independent signals that are being analyzed and separated in the context of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures, specifically focusing on natural speech signals that exhibit piecewise stationary characteristics with varying variances.

Entity-separation_accuracy.label: separation accuracy
Entity-separation_accuracy.description: Separation accuracy refers to the effectiveness of a method in correctly isolating independent signals from a mixture, specifically in the context of natural speech signals, where the proposed method demonstrates superior performance compared to existing state-of-the-art techniques.

Entity-assumed_model.label: assumed model
Entity-assumed_model.description: The 'assumed model' refers to a first-order autoregressive model that the signals are expected to follow in order to achieve nearly statistically efficient separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals.

Entity-varying_variance_in_different_epo.label: varying variances in different epochs
Entity-varying_variance_in_different_epo.description: The phrase 'varying variances in different epochs' refers to the characteristic of signals being analyzed in the study, indicating that the statistical variance of these signals changes over distinct time periods or segments, which is crucial for the proposed method of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures.

Entity-nonstationarity_of_the_original_s.label: nonstationarity of the original signals
Entity-nonstationarity_of_the_original_s.description: Nonstationarity of the original signals refers to the property of signals whose statistical characteristics, such as mean and variance, change over time, indicating that the signals do not have a constant distribution.

Entity-cramr-rao_lower_bound.label: Cramér-Rao lower bound
Entity-cramr-rao_lower_bound.description: The Cramér-Rao lower bound is a theoretical limit that provides a lower bound on the variance of unbiased estimators of a parameter, indicating the best possible precision that can be achieved in estimating that parameter.

Entity-statistically_efficient.label: statistically efficient
Entity-statistically_efficient.description: The term 'statistically efficient' refers to a property of an estimation method that achieves performance close to the Cramér-Rao lower bound, indicating that the method provides estimates with minimal variance under the assumptions of the model used.

Entity-first-order_autoregressive_model.label: first-order autoregressive model
Entity-first-order_autoregressive_model.description: A first-order autoregressive model is a statistical model used in time series analysis where the current value of a variable is regressed on its immediately preceding value, capturing the relationship between consecutive observations.

Entity-each_epoch.label: each epoch
Entity-each_epoch.description: Each epoch refers to distinct time intervals during which the statistical properties of the signals, such as variance, may change, and within which the signals are modeled as following a first-order autoregressive process rather than being independent and identically distributed.

Entity-piecewise_stationary.label: piecewise stationary
Entity-piecewise_stationary.description: Piecewise stationary refers to a statistical property of a signal that exhibits different stationary characteristics in distinct segments or intervals, allowing for variations in parameters such as mean and variance across these segments.

Entity-nonstationarity.label: nonstationarity
Entity-nonstationarity.description: Nonstationarity refers to a statistical property of a process or signal where its statistical characteristics, such as mean and variance, change over time, indicating that the process does not have a constant distribution.

Entity-different_epoch.label: different epochs
Entity-different_epoch.description: Different epochs refer to distinct time intervals during which the statistical properties of the signals, such as variance, change, indicating that the signals are piecewise stationary.

Entity-natural_speech_signal.label: natural speech signals
Entity-natural_speech_signal.description: Natural speech signals refer to the audio signals produced by human speech, encompassing the sounds, intonations, and patterns used in verbal communication.

Entity-variance.label: variances
Entity-variance.description: In the context of the paper, 'variances' refers to the statistical measure of the dispersion of signal amplitudes that change over different time epochs in piecewise stationary signals.

Entity-state-of-the-art_method.label: state-of-the-art methods
Entity-state-of-the-art_method.description: state-of-the-art methods refer to the most advanced and effective techniques or approaches currently available in a particular field, often used as a benchmark for comparison.

Entity-i.i.d_..label: i.i.d.
Entity-i.i.d_..description: i.i.d. stands for 'independent and identically distributed', a statistical property describing a set of random variables that are all drawn from the same probability distribution and are mutually independent.

Entity-epoch.label: epochs
Entity-epoch.description: Epochs refer to distinct periods or intervals of time characterized by specific conditions or events, often used in contexts such as data analysis, history, or scientific studies.

Entity-previous_work.label: previous works
Entity-previous_work.description: previous works refers to earlier research studies or literature that have been conducted on a similar topic or methodology.

summary: The problem of blind separation of underdetermined instantaneous mixtures of independent signals is addressed through a method relying on nonstationarity of the original signals . The signals are assumed to be piecewise stationary with varying variances in different epochs . In comparison with previous works , in this paper it is assumed that the signals are not i.i.d. in each epoch , but obey a first-order autoregressive model . This model was shown to be more appropriate for blind separation of natural speech signals . A separation method is proposed that is nearly statistically efficient -LRB- approaching the corresponding Cramér-Rao lower bound -RRB- , if the separated signals obey the assumed model . In the case of natural speech signals , the method is shown to have separation accuracy better than the state-of-the-art methods .

Predicate-is_addressed_through.label: is addressed through
Predicate-is_addressed_through.description: The predicate 'is addressed through' indicates a relationship where the subject represents a problem, challenge, or concept that is being tackled or solved by the means or approach specified in the object. It implies that the object provides a method, strategy, or framework that facilitates the understanding, resolution, or management of the subject.

Predicate-relies_on.label: relies on
Predicate-relies_on.description: The predicate 'relies on' indicates a dependency relationship where the subject is contingent upon or utilizes the object as a fundamental basis or support for its function, operation, or validity. This implies that the subject cannot effectively operate or achieve its intended purpose without the presence or influence of the object.

Predicate-are_assumed_to_be.label: are assumed to be
Predicate-are_assumed_to_be.description: The predicate 'are assumed to be' indicates a belief or hypothesis regarding the nature or characteristics of the subject, suggesting that the subject is considered to possess the qualities or state described by the object, often based on theoretical reasoning, empirical evidence, or common understanding.

Predicate-are_in.label: are in
Predicate-are_in.description: The predicate 'are in' indicates a relationship of inclusion or presence, where the subject is situated within or associated with the object. It suggests that the subject exists or is found within the context, category, or timeframe represented by the object.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' denotes a relationship of possession or existence between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the qualities or attributes described by the object. It establishes a connection where the subject is seen as the holder or bearer of the object, which can represent physical items, abstract concepts, or specific characteristics.

Predicate-are_not.label: are not
Predicate-are_not.description: The predicate 'are not' serves to establish a negation or denial relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject does not possess the characteristics or qualities defined by the object. It asserts that the subject is distinct from or incompatible with the object in some fundamental way.

Predicate-obey.label: obey
Predicate-obey.description: The predicate 'obey' indicates a relationship where the subject acts in accordance with, or follows the rules, principles, or directives established by the object. It implies a sense of compliance or adherence, suggesting that the subject's behavior or actions are guided by the framework or constraints defined by the object.

Predicate-compares_with.label: compares with
Predicate-compares_with.description: The predicate 'compares with' establishes a relationship between the subject and the object by indicating that the subject is being evaluated or analyzed in relation to the object. This comparison may involve examining similarities, differences, or other relevant aspects, thereby providing a context for understanding the subject's characteristics, contributions, or significance in relation to the object.

Predicate-is_part_of.label: is part of
Predicate-is_part_of.description: The predicate 'is part of' indicates a relationship where the subject is a component, element, or segment that contributes to the whole represented by the object. This connection implies that the subject cannot be fully understood without considering its role within the context of the object, highlighting a hierarchical or structural relationship between the two.

Predicate-is_shown_to_be_more_appropriat.label: is shown to be more appropriate for
Predicate-is_shown_to_be_more_appropriat.description: The predicate 'is shown to be more appropriate for' indicates that the subject has been demonstrated or evidenced to be better suited or more effective in relation to the object. This suggests a comparative evaluation where the subject is assessed against the context or criteria represented by the object, implying that the subject fulfills the requirements or performs better in the specified domain or application.

Predicate-is_proposed.label: is proposed
Predicate-is_proposed.description: The predicate 'is proposed' indicates that the subject is being suggested or put forward as a potential idea, solution, or approach regarding the object. It implies a recommendation or an initial consideration of the subject in relation to the object, often in the context of theoretical or practical applications.

Predicate-is_statistically_efficient.label: is statistically efficient
Predicate-is_statistically_efficient.description: The predicate 'is statistically efficient' establishes a relationship between a subject and an object by indicating that the subject achieves optimal performance in terms of statistical estimation or inference, as defined by the object. In this context, the object often represents a benchmark or standard, such as the Cramér-Rao lower bound, which quantifies the lowest possible variance of an unbiased estimator. Thus, when a subject is described as 'statistically efficient,' it implies that it meets or exceeds the efficiency criteria set by the object, demonstrating superior statistical properties.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a possessive or relational connection between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the object. In the context of the example triple, it implies that the subject (separation method) is associated with or defined by the object (separation accuracy), highlighting a specific attribute or quality that the subject exhibits.

Predicate-is_shown_to_have.label: is shown to have
Predicate-is_shown_to_have.description: The predicate 'is shown to have' indicates that there is evidence or demonstration supporting the existence or presence of a particular quality, characteristic, or attribute in the subject. It connects the subject to the object by asserting that the subject possesses the object in a way that is substantiated by data, research, or observation.

Predicate-is_better_than.label: is better than
Predicate-is_better_than.description: The predicate 'is better than' establishes a comparative relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject possesses a higher quality, performance, or effectiveness in a specific context compared to the object. This comparison suggests a superiority of the subject over the object, often implying that the subject is more desirable or effective in achieving a particular goal or outcome.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject is introducing, showcasing, or demonstrating the object, which typically represents an idea, method, or finding. This connection implies that the subject is providing information or evidence about the object in a manner that is intended to inform or persuade the audience.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or type that falls under the more general category represented by the object. This relationship implies that the subject shares common characteristics or functions with other entities classified under the broader term, thereby situating the subject within a wider conceptual framework.
